page.title: 01FARMING AROUND COOKHAM DEAN
page.content: The area of land between Maidenhead and Marlow forms part of the terraces of the River Thames, and has been extensively farmed for centuries. Today the farms in the area cover almost the full range of agricultural activities; from pig farming to poultry, dairy farming to fruit. The land is predominantly chalk, with pockets of clay and gravel. In recent years several areas of gravel have been extracted by the Summerleaze Gravel Co. At present they are digging gravel from land adjacent to Cannon Court Farm. In most cases the land has been restored to its former use, or has been developed as reservoirs. The river terraces are very steeply sloping, and as a result are unsuitable for agriculture. This land has either been left as pasture, or is covered with mixed woodland.
